==Benefits for users==
+
=="Verified" or "trusted" boot==
â
While users usually do not like restrictions/protections on their hardware, "restrictions" can be used for the purpose of securing the users data on the devices, or to ensure the machine is not infected with malicious software, an example is "verified boot"<ref>http://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/dev/chromium-os/chromiumos-design-docs/verified-boot</ref> in some [[Chromebook]]s with [[Google Chrome OS]]. Other possible "beneficial" uses can also be the case of the OLPC (see bellow).
+
Some devices implement a feature called "verified boot" or "trusted boot", this feature will only allow signed software to run on the device, usually from the device manufacturer. This can be considered a "restriction" is the users do not have the ability to disable the verified boot. "verified boot"<ref>http://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/dev/chromium-os/chromiumos-design-docs/verified-boot</ref> is used on in some [[Chromebook]]s with [[Google Chrome OS]], with the stated goal of ensuring a malware-free system, but can be disabled by the users, by entering into the "developer mode". Another case of trusted boot is the [[One Laptop per Child]] XO laptop which will only boot from software signed by a private crypto key known only to the OLPC nonprofit. However, the laptop and the nonprofit provide a way to disable the restrictions, by requesting a "[[OLPC:Activation and developer keys|developer key]]" unique to that laptop, over the Internet, waiting 24 hours to receive it, installing it, and running the firmware command- "disable-security". The stated goal is to deter mass theft of laptops from children or via distribution channels, by making the laptops refuse to boot, making it hard to reprogram them so they will boot, and delaying the issuance of developer keys to allow time to check whether a key-requesting laptop had been stolen.

==One Laptop Per Child==
  â   â
The [[One Laptop per Child]] XO laptop is shipped with hardware restrictions; it will only boot from software signed by a private crypto key known only to the OLPC nonprofit. However, the laptop and the nonprofit provide a way to disable the restrictions, by requesting a "[[OLPC:Activation and developer keys|developer key]]" unique to your laptop over the Internet, waiting 24 hours to receive it, installing it, and running the firmware command- "disable-security". The stated goal is to deter mass theft of laptops from children or via distribution channels, by making the laptops refuse to boot, making it hard to reprogram them so they will boot, and delaying the issuance of developer keys to allow time to check whether a key-requesting laptop had been stolen. See more at http://wiki.laptop.org/go/Developer_key
